baseline: Ostensibly committed to peace and anti-imperialism, the International Socialist Congress held its final meeting in Basel, Switzerland in 1912, in anticipation of the outbreak of World War I.

prompts: The perceived betrayal of the social - democrats and the organization of the Zimmerwald Left would ultimately set the stage for
baseline: The perceived betrayal of the social-democrats and the organization of the Zimmerwald Left would ultimately set the stage for the emergence of the world's first modern communist parties and the formation of the Third International in 1919.

prompts: The Communist International , also known as the Comintern or the Third International , was formed in 1919 in
baseline: The Communist International, also known as the Comintern or the Third International, was formed in 1919 in the wake of the Russian Revolution, the end of the first World War, and the dissolution of the Second International.

prompts: It was an association of communist political parties from throughout the world dedicated to proletarian internationalism
baseline: It was an association of communist political parties from throughout the world dedicated to proletarian internationalism and the revolutionary overthrow of the world bourgeoisie.

prompts: The 4th World Congress of the Communist International established the legal framework
baseline: The 4th World Congress of the Communist International established the legal framework for internationalist collaboration and the foundation of agricultural and industrial communes within the USSR.

baseline: Up until World War II, between seventy and eighty thousand internationalist-minded workers moved to the Soviet Union from abroad.

baseline: When US presidents, today, claim to speak simultaneously on behalf of their nation and a new world order, they are not placing, side by side in the same utterance, elements from two, clearly separate ideologies; nor are they creating a novel synthesis from the thesis of nationalism and the antithesis of internationalism.

prompts: Free Trade ! What is it ? Why , breaking down the barriers
baseline: Free Trade! What is it? Why, breaking down the barriers that separate nations; those barriers behind which nestle the feelings of pride, revenge, hatred and jealously, which every now and then burst their bounds and deluge whole countries with blood.

baseline: For both intergovernmental organizations and international non-governmental organizations to emerge, nations and peoples had to be strongly aware that they shared certain interests and objectives across national boundaries and they could best solve their many problems by pooling their resources and effecting transnational cooperation, rather than through individual countries' unilateral efforts.

prompts: Its aims are to encourage multilateralism ( world leadership not held by any single country ) and create some formal and
baseline: Its aims are to encourage multilateralism (world leadership not held by any single country) and create some formal and informal interdependence between countries, with some limited supranational powers given to international organisations controlled by those nations via intergovernmental treaties and institutions.

prompts: Internationalism is an important component of socialist political theory , based on the principle
baseline: Internationalism is an important component of socialist political theory, based on the principle that working-class people of all countries must unite across national boundaries and actively oppose nationalism and war in order to overthrow capitalism.

prompts: Unlike the First International , it was a federation of
baseline: Unlike the First International, it was a federation of socialist political parties from various countries, including both reformist and revolutionary groupings.

prompts: If a war threatens to break out , it is the duty of
baseline: If a war threatens to break out, it is the duty of the working classes and their parliamentary representatives in the countries involved supported by the coordinating activity of the International Socialist Bureau to exert every effort in order to prevent the outbreak of war by the means they consider most effective, which naturally vary according to the sharpening of the class struggle and the sharpening of the general political situation.

baseline: The call for internationalist solidarity attracted settlers from countries such as Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Estonia, Germany, Italy, Sweden, Uruguay and the United States.

baseline: He called for a further decentralization of PEN, which has 144 centres in 102 countries.

baseline: This included global economic integration, which had collapsed under World War I and the Great Depression.

baseline: Historically in the international relations of the 1970s and 1980s, globalism and regionalism had been defined somewhat differently due to the Cold War.

baseline: Analysts discussed a globalism vs. regionalism dichotomy, in which globalists believed that international events more often arose from great power competition (then U.S.–Soviet rivalry), whereas regionalists believed they more often arose from local factors.

baseline: While primarily associated with world-systems, it can be used to describe other global trends.

baseline: The term: 'the Globalists' is now frequently used as a pejorative by far-right movements and conspiracy theorists, as in the New World Order; it is sometimes associated with antisemitism, as antisemites frequently appropriate the term to refer to certain Jews.

prompts: In his 2005 book The Collapse of Globalism and the Reinvention of the World , Canadian philosopher John Ralston Saul treated globalism as coterminous
baseline: In his 2005 book The Collapse of Globalism and the Reinvention of the World, Canadian philosopher John Ralston Saul treated globalism as coterminous with neoliberalism and neoliberal globalization.

prompts: Political scientists Joseph Nye and Robert Keohane , major thinkers of liberal institutionalism as a new international relations theory , generalized the term to
baseline: Political scientists Joseph Nye and Robert Keohane, major thinkers of liberal institutionalism as a new international relations theory, generalized the term to argue that globalism refers to any description and explanation of a world which is characterized by networks of connections that span multi-continental distances, while globalization refers to the increase or decline in the degree of globalism.

prompts: Globalization has been used to describe international endeavours begun after World War
baseline: Globalization has been used to describe international endeavours begun after World War II, such as the United Nations, the Warsaw Pact, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Union, and sometimes the later neoliberal and neoconservative policies of nation building and military interventionism between the end of the Cold War in 1991 and the beginning of the war on terror in 2001.

prompts: In their position of unprecedented power , planners formulated policies to shape
baseline: In their position of unprecedented power, planners formulated policies to shape the kind of postwar world they wanted, which in economic terms meant a globe-spanning capitalist order centered exclusively upon the United States.

prompts: This was the period when its global power was at its peak : the United States was the greatest economic
baseline: This was the period when its global power was at its peak: the United States was the greatest economic power the world had known, with the greatest military machine in history.

baseline: Kennan's Policy Planning Staff said: "e have about 50% of the world's wealth but only 6.3% of its population. ...

baseline: This included global economic integration, which had collapsed under World War I and the Great Depression.

baseline: Modern globalism has been linked to the ideas of economic and political integration of countries and economies.

baseline: Global politics, also known as world politics, names both the discipline that studies the political and economic patterns of the world and the field that is being studied.

prompts: One important area of global politics is contestation in the
baseline: One important area of global politics is contestation in the global political sphere over legitimacy.

prompts: Global politics is said by some to be distinct from the field of international politics ( commonly seen as a branch of international relations ) , as it " does not stress the primacy of
baseline: Global politics is said by some to be distinct from the field of international politics (commonly seen as a branch of international relations), as it "does not stress the primacy of intergovernmental relations and transactions".

prompts: This distinction however has not always been held among authors and
baseline: This distinction however has not always been held among authors and political scientists, who often use the term "international politics" to mean global politics.

prompts: It has been suggested that global politics may be best understood as an "
baseline: It has been suggested that global politics may be best understood as an "imaginary" of a political space existing beyond the sub-national, national, and international.

prompts: This imaginary structures global politics as both a field of study and a set of practices , and though it only rose to prominence in
baseline: This imaginary structures global politics as both a field of study and a set of practices, and though it only rose to prominence in the late twentieth century, has longer historical roots stretching back at least to the creation of medieval mappa mundi and to first contact between Afro-Eurasia and the Americas through colonialism and the Age of Sail.

prompts: Europeans , with their global supremacy , imposed their own system
baseline: Europeans, with their global supremacy, imposed their own system and views on others, through envisioning the world as a whole and defining the regions of the world as 'modern' or 'backward'.

prompts: Today , the practices of global politics are defined by values :
baseline: Today, the practices of global politics are defined by values: norms of human rights, ideas of human development, and beliefs such as Internationalism or cosmopolitanism about how we should relate to each.

prompts: Over the last couple of decades cosmopolitanism has become one of the
baseline: Over the last couple of decades cosmopolitanism has become one of the key contested ideologies of global politics:

prompts: Cosmopolitanism can be defined as a global politics that , firstly , projects a sociality of
baseline: Cosmopolitanism can be defined as a global politics that, firstly, projects a sociality of common political engagement among all human beings across the globe, and, secondly, suggests that this sociality should be either ethically or organizationally privileged over other forms of sociality.

prompts: The intensification of globalization led some writers to suggest that states were
baseline: The intensification of globalization led some writers to suggest that states were no longer relevant to global politics.

prompts: On the other hand , other commentators have been arguing that states have
baseline: On the other hand, other commentators have been arguing that states have remained essential to global politics.

baseline: They have been rejuvenated because, among other reasons, they are still the primary providers of (military) security in the global arena; they are still the paramount loci for articulating the voices of (procedurally democratic) national communities, and for ordering their interactions with similar polities; and finally, they are indispensable to relations of (unequal) economic exchange insofar as they legitimize and enforce the global legal frameworks that enable globalization in the first place.

baseline: Global politics, also known as world politics, names both the discipline that studies the political and economic patterns of the world and the field that is being studied.

prompts: The way in which modern world politics is implemented is structured by
baseline: The way in which modern world politics is implemented is structured by a set of interpretations dating back to the rise of the European powers.

prompts: They were able to overtake
baseline: They were able to overtake the rest of the world in terms of economic and military power.

prompts: Europeans , with their global supremacy , imposed their own system
baseline: Europeans, with their global supremacy, imposed their own system and views on others, through envisioning the world as a whole and defining the regions of the world as 'modern' or 'backward'.

prompts: They saw nation statehood as the best and highest form of political organization , therefore viewing world politics as
baseline: They saw nation statehood as the best and highest form of political organization, therefore viewing world politics as the result of the pursuit of hegemony by competing states.

prompts: The modern world politics perspective is often identified with the works
baseline: The modern world politics perspective is often identified with the works, in particular their 1972 work Transnational Relations and World Politics.

prompts: The United States 1914 to ( predicted ) 2030 ; beginning with World War
baseline: The United States 1914 to (predicted) 2030; beginning with World War I and two.

prompts: 2 , World power , which lasts for ' about
baseline: 2, World power, which lasts for 'about one generation'.

prompts: Great Britain , 1815 - 1945 ; ended by Germany 's
baseline: Great Britain, 1815-1945; ended by Germany's challenge in two World Wars, and the postwar settlement, including the World Bank, IMF, GATT, the United Nations and NATO

prompts: This imaginary structures global politics as both a field of study and a set of practices , and though it only rose to prominence in
baseline: This imaginary structures global politics as both a field of study and a set of practices, and though it only rose to prominence in the late twentieth century, has longer historical roots stretching back at least to the creation of medieval mappa mundi and to first contact between Afro-Eurasia and the Americas through colonialism and the Age of Sail.

prompts: Earlier definitions of globality referred to the quality
baseline: Earlier definitions of globality referred to the quality of being global or universal.

prompts: Pundits like Daniel Yergin now employ the concept of globality to speculate about the end
baseline: Pundits like Daniel Yergin now employ the concept of globality to speculate about the end-state of globalization, a hypothetical condition in which the process of globalization is complete or nearly so, barriers have fallen, and "a new global reality" is emerging.

prompts: Globality is the consciousness of
baseline: Globality is the consciousness of the world as a single place.

prompts: It signifies the spreading and deepening consciousness of the world - as - a - whole and could thus be considered the phenomenological aspect
baseline: It signifies the spreading and deepening consciousness of the world-as-a-whole and could thus be considered the phenomenological aspect of globalization, which Robertson defined as "the compression of the world and the intensification of consciousness of the world as a whole" (Robertson 1992, p. 34).

prompts: This increase in global interactions has caused a growth in
baseline: This increase in global interactions has caused a growth in international trade and the exchange of ideas, beliefs, and culture.

prompts: The expansion of global markets liberalizes the economic activities
baseline: The expansion of global markets liberalizes the economic activities of the exchange of goods and funds.

prompts: Removal of cross - border trade barriers has made the formation of
baseline: Removal of cross-border trade barriers has made the formation of global markets more feasible.

prompts: The term global city was subsequently popularized by sociologist Saskia
baseline: The term global city was subsequently popularized by sociologist Saskia Sassen in her work The Global City: New York, London, Tokyo (1991).

prompts: Although in its simplistic sense globalization refers to the widening
baseline: Although in its simplistic sense globalization refers to the widening, deepening and speeding up of global interconnection, such a definition begs further elaboration. ...

prompts: At one end of the continuum lie social and economic relations and networks which are organized on a local
baseline: At one end of the continuum lie social and economic relations and networks which are organized on a local and/or national basis; at the other end lie social and economic relations and networks which crystallize on the wider scale of regional and global interactions.

prompts: Held and his co - writers ' definition of globalization in that same book as " transformation in the spatial organization of social relations and transactions — assessed in terms of
baseline: Held and his co-writers' definition of globalization in that same book as "transformation in the spatial organization of social relations and transactions—assessed in terms of their extensity, intensity, velocity and impact—generating transcontinental or inter-regional flows" was called "probably the most widely-cited definition" in the 2014 DHL Global Connectiveness Index.

prompts: Manfred Steger , professor of global studies and research leader in the Global Cities Institute at RMIT University , identifies four main empirical
baseline: Manfred Steger, professor of global studies and research leader in the Global Cities Institute at RMIT University, identifies four main empirical dimensions of globalization: economic, political, cultural, and ecological.

prompts: James and Steger stated that the concept of globalization " emerged from the intersection
baseline: James and Steger stated that the concept of globalization "emerged from the intersection of four interrelated sets of 'communities of practice' (Wenger, 1998): academics, journalists, publishers/editors, and librarians.": 424  They note the term was used "in education to describe the global life of the mind"; in international relations to describe the extension of the European Common Market, and in journalism to describe how the "American Negro and his problem are taking on a global significance".

prompts: The interactions of states were not on a global scale and most often were confined to Asia ,
baseline: The interactions of states were not on a global scale and most often were confined to Asia, North Africa, the Middle East, and certain parts of Europe.

prompts: This is one of the driving forces behind global connections and trade ; without either , globalization would not have emerged the way it
baseline: This is one of the driving forces behind global connections and trade; without either, globalization would not have emerged the way it did and states would still be dependent on their own production and resources to work.

prompts: An alternative view from historians Dennis Flynn and Arturo Giraldez , postulated that : globalization
baseline: An alternative view from historians Dennis Flynn and Arturo Giraldez, postulated that: globalization began with the first circumnavigation of the globe under the Magellan-Elcano expedition which preluded the rise of global silver trade.

prompts: Early modern globalization is distinguished from modern globalization on the basis of expansionism , the method of managing global trade ,
baseline: Early modern globalization is distinguished from modern globalization on the basis of expansionism, the method of managing global trade, and the level of information exchange.

prompts: During the 19th and early 20th centuries , the United Kingdom was a global superpower
baseline: During the 19th and early 20th centuries, the United Kingdom was a global superpower.

prompts: The approach of using global agreements to advance trade stumbled with
baseline: The approach of using global agreements to advance trade stumbled with the failure of the Doha Development Round of trade negotiation.

prompts: These programs allowed the World Bank and the IMF to become global financial market
baseline: These programs allowed the World Bank and the IMF to become global financial market regulators that would promote neoliberalism and the creation of free markets for multinational corporations on a global scale.

prompts: The revolutions of 1989 and subsequent liberalization in many parts of the world resulted in a significant
baseline: The revolutions of 1989 and subsequent liberalization in many parts of the world resulted in a significant expansion of global interconnectedness.

prompts: One influential event was the late 2000s recession , which was associated with lower growth
baseline: One influential event was the late 2000s recession, which was associated with lower growth (in areas such as cross-border phone calls and Skype usage) or even temporarily negative growth (in areas such as trade) of global interconnectedness.

prompts: The 2021–2022 global supply chain crisis resulted from temporary shutdowns
baseline: The 2021–2022 global supply chain crisis resulted from temporary shutdowns of manufacturing and transportation facilities, and labor shortages.

prompts: The economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine included a blockade of
baseline: The economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine included a blockade of Ukrainian ports and international sanctions on Russia, resulting in some de-coupling of the Russian economy with global trade, especially with the European Union and other Western countries.

prompts: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution
baseline: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution of international trade regulations as well as tariffs, taxes, and other impediments that suppresses global trade, economic globalization is the process of increasing economic integration between countries, leading to the emergence of a global marketplace or a single world market.

prompts: Likewise , it also comprises globalization of markets ; which is defined as the union
baseline: Likewise, it also comprises globalization of markets; which is defined as the union of different and separate markets into a massive global marketplace.

prompts: He believes that the global capital experienced today is due
baseline: He believes that the global capital experienced today is due to a new and distinct form of globalization which began in the 1980s.

prompts: One important aspect of Robinson 's globalization theory is that production of
baseline: One important aspect of Robinson's globalization theory is that production of goods are increasingly global.

prompts: McDonald 's is commonly seen as a symbol of globalization , often called McDonaldization of global
baseline: McDonald's is commonly seen as a symbol of globalization, often called McDonaldization of global society.

prompts: Though the term " World Music " was originally intended for ethnic -
baseline: Though the term "World Music" was originally intended for ethnic-specific music, globalization is now expanding its scope such that the term often includes hybrid subgenres such as "world fusion", "global fusion", "ethnic fusion", and worldbeat.

prompts: That system includes national governments ,
baseline: That system includes national governments, their governmental and intergovernmental organizations as well as government-independent elements of global civil society such as international non-governmental organizations and social movement organizations.

prompts: Multi - level governance gives expression to the idea that there are many interacting authority
baseline: Multi-level governance gives expression to the idea that there are many interacting authority structures at work in the emergent global political economy.

prompts: Philanthropic organizations with global missions are also coming to the forefront
baseline: Philanthropic organizations with global missions are also coming to the forefront of humanitarian efforts; charities such as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Accion International, the Acumen Fund (now Acumen) and the Echoing Green have combined the business model with philanthropy, giving rise to business organizations such as the Global Philanthropy Group and new associations of philanthropists such as the Global Philanthropy Forum.

prompts: Scholars also occasionally discuss other , less
baseline: Scholars also occasionally discuss other, less common dimensions of globalization, such as environmental globalization (the internationally coordinated practices and regulations, often in the form of international treaties, regarding environmental protection) or military globalization (growth in global extent and scope of security relationships).

prompts: The development of global cross - cultural competence in the workforce through ad - hoc training has deserved increasing attention in
baseline: The development of global cross-cultural competence in the workforce through ad-hoc training has deserved increasing attention in recent times.

prompts: The global digital divide : Computers per
baseline: The global digital divide: Computers per 100 people per 2006

prompts: Speed of global communications was limited by the maximum
baseline: Speed of global communications was limited by the maximum speed of courier services (especially horses and ships) until the mid-19th century.

prompts: Globalization can be spread by Global journalism which provides massive information and
baseline: Globalization can be spread by Global journalism which provides massive information and relies on the internet to interact, "makes it into an everyday routine to investigate how people and their actions, practices, problems, life conditions, etc. in different parts of the world are interrelated. possible to assume that global threats such as climate change precipitate the further establishment of global journalism."

prompts: Efficient and inexpensive transportation has left few places inaccessible , and increased global trade has
baseline: Efficient and inexpensive transportation has left few places inaccessible, and increased global trade has brought more and more people into contact with animal diseases that have subsequently jumped species barriers (see zoonosis).

prompts: This has caused a detrimental impact on the global economy , particularly for SME 's and Microbusinesses with unlimited liability / self - employed , leaving them
baseline: This has caused a detrimental impact on the global economy, particularly for SME's and Microbusinesses with unlimited liability/self-employed, leaving them vulnerable to financial difficulties, increasing the market share for oligopolistic markets as well as increasing the barriers of entry.

prompts: The DHL Global Connectedness Index studies four main types
baseline: The DHL Global Connectedness Index studies four main types of cross-border flow: trade (in both goods and services), information, people (including tourists, students, and migrants), and capital.

prompts: It shows that the depth of global integration fell by about one
baseline: It shows that the depth of global integration fell by about one-tenth after 2008, but by 2013 had recovered well above its pre-crash peak.

prompts: Antagonists view one or more globalizing processes as detrimental to social well - being on a global or local scale ; this includes those who focus
baseline: Antagonists view one or more globalizing processes as detrimental to social well-being on a global or local scale; this includes those who focus on social or natural sustainability of long-term and continuous economic expansion, the social structural inequality caused by these processes, and the colonial, imperialistic, or hegemonic ethnocentrism, cultural assimilation and cultural appropriation that underlie such processes.

prompts: As a complex and multifaceted phenomenon , globalization is considered by some as
baseline: As a complex and multifaceted phenomenon, globalization is considered by some as a form of capitalist expansion which entails the integration of local and national economies into a global, unregulated market economy.

prompts: The flow of migrants to advanced economies has been claimed to provide a
baseline: The flow of migrants to advanced economies has been claimed to provide a means through which global wages converge.

prompts: They advocate global institutions and policies that they believe better address the
baseline: They advocate global institutions and policies that they believe better address the moral claims of poor and working classes as well as environmental concerns.

prompts: Democratic globalization is a movement towards an institutional system of global democracy that would give world citizens a
baseline: Democratic globalization is a movement towards an institutional system of global democracy that would give world citizens a say in political organizations.

prompts: Advocates of democratic globalization argue that economic expansion and development should be the first phase of democratic globalization , which is to be followed by a phase
baseline: Advocates of democratic globalization argue that economic expansion and development should be the first phase of democratic globalization, which is to be followed by a phase of building global political institutions.

prompts: Global civics suggests that civics can be understood , in a
baseline: Global civics suggests that civics can be understood, in a global sense, as a social contract between global citizens in the age of interdependence and interaction.

prompts: An early incarnation of this sentiment can be found in Socrates ,
baseline: An early incarnation of this sentiment can be found in Socrates, whom Plutarch quoted as saying: "I am not an Athenian, or a Greek, but a citizen of the world." In an increasingly interdependent world, world citizens need a compass to frame their mindsets and create a shared consciousness and sense of global responsibility in world issues such as environmental problems and nuclear proliferation.

prompts: Baha'i - inspired author Meyjes , while favoring the single world
baseline: Baha'i-inspired author Meyjes, while favoring the single world community and emergent global consciousness, warns of globalization as a cloak for an expeditious economic, social, and cultural Anglo-dominance that is insufficiently inclusive to inform the emergence of an optimal world civilization.

prompts: Arms control and disarmament agreements , including the Strategic Arms
baseline: Arms control and disarmament agreements, including the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (see START I, START II, START III, and New START) and the establishment of NATO's Partnership for Peace, the Russia NATO Council, and the G8 Global Partnership against the Spread of Weapons and Materials of Mass Destruction, constitute concrete initiatives of arms control and de-nuclearization.

prompts: Increasing integration of these financial markets between countries leads to the emergence
baseline: Increasing integration of these financial markets between countries leads to the emergence of a global capital marketplace or a single world market.

prompts: Those opposed to capital market integration on the basis of human rights issues are especially disturbed by the various
baseline: Those opposed to capital market integration on the basis of human rights issues are especially disturbed by the various abuses which they think are perpetuated by global and international institutions that, they say, promote neoliberalism without regard to ethical standards.

prompts: Corporatist ideology , which privileges the rights of corporations ( artificial or juridical persons ) over those of natural persons , is an underlying factor
baseline: Corporatist ideology, which privileges the rights of corporations (artificial or juridical persons) over those of natural persons, is an underlying factor in the recent rapid expansion of global commerce.

prompts: Social activists hold materialism is connected
baseline: Social activists hold materialism is connected to global retail merchandizing and supplier convergence, war, greed, anomie, crime, environmental degradation, and general social malaise and discontent.

prompts: The global justice movement is the loose collection of individuals and groups — often referred to as a
baseline: The global justice movement is the loose collection of individuals and groups—often referred to as a "movement of movements"—who advocate fair trade rules and perceive current institutions of global economic integration as problems.

prompts: Those involved , however , frequently deny that they are
baseline: Those involved, however, frequently deny that they are anti-globalization, insisting that they support the globalization of communication and people and oppose only the global expansion of corporate power.

prompts: Social inequality within and between nations , including a growing global
baseline: Social inequality within and between nations, including a growing global digital divide, is a focal point of the movement.

prompts: Global share of wealth by
baseline: Global share of wealth by wealth group, Credit Suisse, 2017

prompts: Those who oppose global governance typically do so on objections
baseline: Those who oppose global governance typically do so on objections that the idea is unfeasible, inevitably oppressive, or simply unnecessary.

prompts: Environmentalist concerns with globalization include issues such as
baseline: Environmentalist concerns with globalization include issues such as global warming, global water supply and water crises, inequity in energy consumption and energy conservation, transnational air pollution and pollution of the world ocean, overpopulation, world habitat sustainability, deforestation, biodiversity loss and species extinction.

prompts: Some argue that Northern corporations are increasingly exploiting resources of less
baseline: Some argue that Northern corporations are increasingly exploiting resources of less wealthy countries for their global activities while it is the South that is disproportionately bearing the environmental burden of the globalized economy.

prompts: The term globalization first appeared in the early 20th century ( supplanting an earlier French term mondialisation ) , developed its current meaning
baseline: The term globalization first appeared in the early 20th century (supplanting an earlier French term mondialisation), developed its current meaning sometime in the second half of the 20th century, and came into popular use in the 1990s to describe the unprecedented international connectivity of the post–Cold War world.

prompts: Though many scholars place the origins of globalization in modern times , others trace its history to
baseline: Though many scholars place the origins of globalization in modern times, others trace its history to long before the European Age of Discovery and voyages to the New World, and some even to the third millennium BCE.

prompts: Large - scale globalization began in the 1820s , and in the late 19th century and early 20th century drove a rapid expansion
baseline: Large-scale globalization began in the 1820s, and in the late 19th century and early 20th century drove a rapid expansion in the connectivity of the world's economies and cultures.

prompts: Though often treated as synonyms , in French , globalization is seen as a stage
baseline: Though often treated as synonyms, in French, globalization is seen as a stage following mondialisation, a stage that implies the dissolution of national identities and the abolishment of borders inside the world network of economic exchanges.

prompts: In 1848 , Karl Marx noticed the increasing level of national
baseline: In 1848, Karl Marx noticed the increasing level of national inter-dependence brought on by capitalism, and predicted the universal character of the modern world society.

prompts: The bourgeoisie has through its exploitation of the world market given a cosmopolitan character
baseline: The bourgeoisie has through its exploitation of the world market given a cosmopolitan character to production and consumption in every country.

prompts: Sociologists Martin Albrow and Elizabeth King define globalization as "
baseline: Sociologists Martin Albrow and Elizabeth King define globalization as "all those processes by which the people of the world are incorporated into a single world society." In The Consequences of Modernity, Anthony Giddens writes: "Globalization can thus be defined as the intensification of worldwide social relations which link distant localities in such a way that local happenings are shaped by events occurring many miles away and vice versa." In 1992, Roland Robertson, professor of sociology at the University of Aberdeen and an early writer in the field, described globalization as "the compression of the world and the intensification of the consciousness of the world as a whole."

prompts: ... is the process of world shrinkage , of distances getting shorter , things
baseline: ...is the process of world shrinkage, of distances getting shorter, things moving closer.

prompts: It pertains to the increasing ease with which somebody on one side of the world can interact , to mutual
baseline: It pertains to the increasing ease with which somebody on one side of the world can interact, to mutual benefit, with somebody on the other side of the world.

prompts: Globalization is the extension of social relations across world - space , defining that world -
baseline: Globalization is the extension of social relations across world-space, defining that world-space in terms of the historically variable ways that it has been practiced and socially understood through changing world-time.

prompts: He calls the transmission of ideas , images , knowledge , and information across world - space disembodied globalization , maintaining that it is
baseline: He calls the transmission of ideas, images, knowledge, and information across world-space disembodied globalization, maintaining that it is currently the dominant form of globalization.

prompts: Friedman popularized the term " flat world " , arguing that globalized trade
baseline: Friedman popularized the term "flat world", arguing that globalized trade, outsourcing, supply-chaining, and political forces had permanently changed the world, for better and worse.

prompts: The 13th century world - system , as described by Janet Abu
baseline: The 13th century world-system, as described by Janet Abu-Lughod

prompts: Because it predated the Great Divergence in the nineteenth century , where Western Europe pulled ahead of the
baseline: Because it predated the Great Divergence in the nineteenth century, where Western Europe pulled ahead of the rest of the world in terms of industrial production and economic output, archaic globalization was a phenomenon that was driven not only by Europe but also by other economically developed Old World centers such as Gujarat, Bengal, coastal China, and Japan.

prompts: Native New World crops exchanged globally ( clockwise
baseline: Native New World crops exchanged globally (clockwise): Maize, tomato, potato, vanilla, rubber, cacao, tobacco

prompts: In the 17th century , world trade developed further when chartered
baseline: In the 17th century, world trade developed further when chartered companies like the British East India Company (founded in 1600) and the Dutch East India Company (founded in 1602, often described as the first multinational corporation in which stock was offered) were established.

prompts: After World War II , work by politicians led to the agreements
baseline: After World War II, work by politicians led to the agreements of the Bretton Woods Conference, in which major governments laid down the framework for international monetary policy, commerce, and finance, and the founding of several international institutions intended to facilitate economic growth by lowering trade barriers.

prompts: GATT 's successor was the World Trade Organization ( WTO ) , which provided a framework for
baseline: GATT's successor was the World Trade Organization (WTO), which provided a framework for negotiating and formalizing trade agreements and a dispute resolution process.

prompts: Exports nearly doubled from 8.5 %
baseline: Exports nearly doubled from 8.5% of total gross world product in 1970 to 16.2% in 2001.

prompts: Student exchange programs became popular after World War II , and are intended to increase the
baseline: Student exchange programs became popular after World War II, and are intended to increase the participants' understanding and tolerance of other cultures, as well as improving their language skills and broadening their social horizons.

prompts: Comet , the world 's first commercial jet airliner , entered service in 1949
baseline: Comet, the world's first commercial jet airliner, entered service in 1949.

prompts: These neoliberal policies were introduced to many developing countries in the
baseline: These neoliberal policies were introduced to many developing countries in the form of structural adjustment programs (SAPs) that were implemented by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

prompts: These programs allowed the World Bank and the IMF to become global financial market
baseline: These programs allowed the World Bank and the IMF to become global financial market regulators that would promote neoliberalism and the creation of free markets for multinational corporations on a global scale.

prompts: With a population of 1.4 billion , China is the world 's
baseline: With a population of 1.4 billion, China is the world's second-largest economy.

prompts: This slowed down from the 1910s onward due to the World Wars and the Cold War , but picked up again in
baseline: This slowed down from the 1910s onward due to the World Wars and the Cold War, but picked up again in the 1980s and 1990s.

prompts: The revolutions of 1989 and subsequent liberalization in many parts of the world resulted in a significant
baseline: The revolutions of 1989 and subsequent liberalization in many parts of the world resulted in a significant expansion of global interconnectedness.

prompts: As economic integration intensified workers moved to areas with higher wages and most of the developing world oriented toward
baseline: As economic integration intensified workers moved to areas with higher wages and most of the developing world oriented toward the international market economy.

prompts: The collapse of the Soviet Union not only ended the Cold War
baseline: The collapse of the Soviet Union not only ended the Cold War's division of the world – it also left the United States its sole policeman and an unfettered advocate of free market.

prompts: Other developments as dramatic were the Internet 's becoming influential in connecting
baseline: Other developments as dramatic were the Internet's becoming influential in connecting people across the world; As of June 2012, more than 2.4 billion people—over a third of the world's human population—have used the services of the Internet.

prompts: Economic globalization is the increasing economic
baseline: Economic globalization is the increasing economic interdependence of national economies across the world through a rapid increase in cross-border movement of goods, services, technology, and capital.

prompts: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution
baseline: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution of international trade regulations as well as tariffs, taxes, and other impediments that suppresses global trade, economic globalization is the process of increasing economic integration between countries, leading to the emergence of a global marketplace or a single world market.

prompts: Arguably , the most significant free - trade area in the world is the European Union
baseline: Arguably, the most significant free-trade area in the world is the European Union, a politico-economic union of 27 member states that are primarily located in Europe.

prompts: Robinson 's theoretical approach to globalization is a critique of
baseline: Robinson's theoretical approach to globalization is a critique of Wallerstein's World Systems Theory.

prompts: Cultural globalization refers to the transmission of ideas , meanings , and values around the world in such a way as to extend and intensify social
baseline: Cultural globalization refers to the transmission of ideas, meanings, and values around the world in such a way as to extend and intensify social relations.

prompts: The FIFA World Cup is the most widely viewed and followed sporting
baseline: The FIFA World Cup is the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the world, exceeding even the Olympic Games; a ninth of the entire population of the planet watched the 2006 FIFA World Cup Final.

prompts: Globalization gave support to the world music phenomenon by allowing music from developing
baseline: Globalization gave support to the world music phenomenon by allowing music from developing countries to reach broader audiences.

prompts: Though the term " World Music " was originally intended for ethnic -
baseline: Though the term "World Music" was originally intended for ethnic-specific music, globalization is now expanding its scope such that the term often includes hybrid subgenres such as "world fusion", "global fusion", "ethnic fusion", and worldbeat.

prompts: Use of chili pepper has spread from the Americas to cuisines around the world , including Thailand , Korea
baseline: Use of chili pepper has spread from the Americas to cuisines around the world, including Thailand, Korea, China, and Italy.

prompts: Globalization is a diverse phenomenon that relates to a multilateral
baseline: Globalization is a diverse phenomenon that relates to a multilateral political world and to the increase of cultural objects and markets between countries.

prompts: U.S. military presence around the world
baseline: U.S. military presence around the world in 2007.

prompts: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation projects include a current multibillion
baseline: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation projects include a current multibillion-dollar commitment to funding immunizations in some of the world's more impoverished but rapidly growing countries.

prompts: The World Tourism Organization announced that the number of tourists who require a visa before
baseline: The World Tourism Organization announced that the number of tourists who require a visa before traveling was at its lowest level ever in 2015.

prompts: According to the International Labour Organization , as of 2014 there were an estimated 232
baseline: According to the International Labour Organization, as of 2014 there were an estimated 232 million international migrants in the world (defined as persons outside their country of origin for 12 months or more) and approximately half of them were estimated to be economically active (i.e. being employed or seeking employment).

prompts: Globalization can be spread by Global journalism which provides massive information and
baseline: Globalization can be spread by Global journalism which provides massive information and relies on the internet to interact, "makes it into an everyday routine to investigate how people and their actions, practices, problems, life conditions, etc. in different parts of the world are interrelated. possible to assume that global threats such as climate change precipitate the further establishment of global journalism."

prompts: In the current era of globalization , the world is more interdependent than
baseline: In the current era of globalization, the world is more interdependent than at any other time.

prompts: As of April   6 , 2020 , the U.S. has the most confirmed
baseline: As of April 6, 2020, the U.S. has the most confirmed active cases in the world.

prompts: The European Union – Mercosur free trade agreement , which would form one of the
baseline: The European Union–Mercosur free trade agreement, which would form one of the world's largest free trade areas, has been denounced by environmental activists and indigenous rights campaigners.

prompts: Gregory Mankiw , " Few propositions command as much consensus among professional economists as that open world trade increases economic growth and
baseline: Gregory Mankiw, "Few propositions command as much consensus among professional economists as that open world trade increases economic growth and raises living standards." In a survey of leading economists, none disagreed with the notion that "freer trade improves productive efficiency and offers consumers better choices, and in the long run these gains are much larger than any effects on employment." Most economists would agree that although increasing returns to scale might mean that certain industry could settle in a geographical area without any strong economic reason derived from comparative advantage, this is not a reason to argue against free trade because the absolute level of output enjoyed by both "winner" and "loser" will increase with the "winner" gaining more than the "loser" but both gaining more than before in an absolute level.

prompts: In the book The End of Poverty , Jeffrey Sachs discusses how many factors
baseline: In the book The End of Poverty, Jeffrey Sachs discusses how many factors can affect a country's ability to enter the world market, including government corruption; legal and social disparities based on gender, ethnicity, or caste; diseases such as AIDS and malaria; lack of infrastructure (including transportation, communications, health, and trade); unstable political landscapes; protectionism; and geographic barriers.

prompts: He argues that many of them lack a basic understanding
baseline: He argues that many of them lack a basic understanding of comparative advantage and its importance in today's world.

prompts: Like this , the British economic journalist Martin Wolf says that incomes of
baseline: Like this, the British economic journalist Martin Wolf says that incomes of poor developing countries, with more than half the world's population, grew substantially faster than those of the world's richest countries that remained relatively stable in its growth, leading to reduced international inequality and the incidence of poverty.

prompts: Certain demographic changes in the developing world after active economic liberalization and international integration resulted in rising general
baseline: Certain demographic changes in the developing world after active economic liberalization and international integration resulted in rising general welfare and, hence, reduced inequality.

prompts: According to Wolf , in the developing world as a
baseline: According to Wolf, in the developing world as a whole, life expectancy rose by four months each year after 1970 and infant mortality rate declined from 107 per thousand in 1970 to 58 in 2000 due to improvements in standards of living and health conditions.

prompts: Furthermore , the reduction in fertility rate in the developing world as a
baseline: Furthermore, the reduction in fertility rate in the developing world as a whole from 4.1 births per woman in 1980 to 2.8 in 2000 indicates improved education level of women on fertility, and control of fewer children with more parental attention and investment.

prompts: Democratic globalization is a movement towards an institutional system of global democracy that would give world citizens a
baseline: Democratic globalization is a movement towards an institutional system of global democracy that would give world citizens a say in political organizations.

prompts: Francesco Stipo , Director of the United States Association of the Club of Rome , advocates unifying nations under
baseline: Francesco Stipo, Director of the United States Association of the Club of Rome, advocates unifying nations under a world government, suggesting that it "should reflect the political and economic balances of world nations.

prompts: A world confederation would not supersede the authority of the State governments but rather complement it , as
baseline: A world confederation would not supersede the authority of the State governments but rather complement it, as both the States and the world authority would have power within their sphere of competence".

prompts: World citizen has a variety of similar meanings , often referring to a person
baseline: World citizen has a variety of similar meanings, often referring to a person who disapproves of traditional geopolitical divisions derived from national citizenship.

prompts: An early incarnation of this sentiment can be found in Socrates ,
baseline: An early incarnation of this sentiment can be found in Socrates, whom Plutarch quoted as saying: "I am not an Athenian, or a Greek, but a citizen of the world." In an increasingly interdependent world, world citizens need a compass to frame their mindsets and create a shared consciousness and sense of global responsibility in world issues such as environmental problems and nuclear proliferation.

prompts: Baha'i - inspired author Meyjes , while favoring the single world
baseline: Baha'i-inspired author Meyjes, while favoring the single world community and emergent global consciousness, warns of globalization as a cloak for an expeditious economic, social, and cultural Anglo-dominance that is insufficiently inclusive to inform the emergence of an optimal world civilization.

prompts: His view suggested that globalization would lead to a world
baseline: His view suggested that globalization would lead to a world where people from all countries will become more integrated and aware of common interests and shared humanity.

prompts: According to Lasch , the new elites , i.e. those who are in the top 20 % in terms of income , through globalization which allows total mobility of
baseline: According to Lasch, the new elites, i.e. those who are in the top 20% in terms of income, through globalization which allows total mobility of capital, no longer live in the same world as their fellow-citizens.

prompts: The denationalization of business enterprise tends to produce a class who
baseline: The denationalization of business enterprise tends to produce a class who see themselves as "world citizens, but without accepting ... any of the obligations that citizenship in a polity normally implies".

prompts: One of the most infamous tactics of the movement is the Battle of
baseline: One of the most infamous tactics of the movement is the Battle of Seattle in 1999, where there were protests against the World Trade Organization's Third Ministerial Meeting.

prompts: All over the world , the movement has held protests outside meetings
baseline: All over the world, the movement has held protests outside meetings of institutions such as the WTO, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the World Economic Forum, and the Group of Eight (G8).

prompts: Increasing integration of these financial markets between countries leads to the emergence
baseline: Increasing integration of these financial markets between countries leads to the emergence of a global capital marketplace or a single world market.

prompts: Common targets include the World Bank
baseline: Common targets include the World Bank (WB), International Monetary Fund (IMF), the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the World Trade Organization (WTO) and free trade treaties like the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA), the Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI) and the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS).

prompts: In light of the economic gap between rich and poor countries , movement adherents claim free trade without
baseline: In light of the economic gap between rich and poor countries, movement adherents claim free trade without measures in place to protect the under-capitalized will contribute only to the strengthening the power of industrialized nations (often termed the "North" in opposition to the developing world's "South").

prompts: Differences in national income equality around the world as measured by the national
baseline: Differences in national income equality around the world as measured by the national Gini coefficient, as of 2018

baseline: The economies of the world have developed unevenly, historically, such that entire geographical regions were left mired in poverty and disease while others began to reduce poverty and disease on a wholesale basis.

baseline: If we look at the Gini coefficient for world income, since the late 1980s, the gap between some regions has markedly narrowed—between Asia and the advanced economies of the West, for example—but huge gaps remain globally.

prompts: By 2013 , 85 multibillionaires had amassed wealth equivalent to
baseline: By 2013, 85 multibillionaires had amassed wealth equivalent to all the wealth owned by the poorest half (3.5 billion) of the world's total population of 7 billion.

baseline: Beginning in the 1930s, opposition arose to the idea of a world government, as advocated by organizations such as the World Federalist Movement (WFM).

prompts: Environmentalist concerns with globalization include issues such as
baseline: Environmentalist concerns with globalization include issues such as global warming, global water supply and water crises, inequity in energy consumption and energy conservation, transnational air pollution and pollution of the world ocean, overpopulation, world habitat sustainability, deforestation, biodiversity loss and species extinction.

prompts: The European Union – Mercosur Free Trade Agreement , which would form one of the
baseline: The European Union–Mercosur Free Trade Agreement, which would form one of the world's largest free trade areas, has been denounced by environmental activists and indigenous rights campaigners.

prompts: This improvement causes an increase in the world 's food supply which encourages improved food security
baseline: This improvement causes an increase in the world's food supply which encourages improved food security.

prompts: Many countries then shifted to bilateral or
baseline: Many countries then shifted to bilateral or smaller multilateral agreements, such as the 2011 United States–Korea Free Trade Agreement.

prompts: Since the 1970s , aviation has become increasingly affordable to
baseline: Since the 1970s, aviation has become increasingly affordable to middle classes in developed countries.

prompts: In the 1990s , the growth of low - cost communication networks cut the cost of
baseline: In the 1990s, the growth of low-cost communication networks cut the cost of communicating between countries.

prompts: These neoliberal policies were introduced to many developing countries in the
baseline: These neoliberal policies were introduced to many developing countries in the form of structural adjustment programs (SAPs) that were implemented by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

prompts: Most migration occurred between the developing countries and least developed countries ( LDCs
baseline: Most migration occurred between the developing countries and least developed countries (LDCs).

prompts: The economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic included a massive decline
baseline: The economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic included a massive decline in tourism and international business travel as many countries temporarily closed borders.

prompts: The economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine included a blockade of
baseline: The economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine included a blockade of Ukrainian ports and international sanctions on Russia, resulting in some de-coupling of the Russian economy with global trade, especially with the European Union and other Western countries.

prompts: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution
baseline: Whereas the globalization of business is centered around the diminution of international trade regulations as well as tariffs, taxes, and other impediments that suppresses global trade, economic globalization is the process of increasing economic integration between countries, leading to the emergence of a global marketplace or a single world market.

prompts: A multinational corporation , or worldwide enterprise , is an organization that
baseline: A multinational corporation, or worldwide enterprise, is an organization that owns or controls the production of goods or services in one or more countries other than their home country.

prompts: A free - trade area is the region encompassing a trade bloc
baseline: A free-trade area is the region encompassing a trade bloc whose member countries have signed a free-trade agreement (FTA).

prompts: Such agreements involve cooperation between at least two countries to reduce trade barriers
baseline: Such agreements involve cooperation between at least two countries to reduce trade barriers –  import quotas and tariffs –  and to increase trade of goods and services with each other.

prompts: If people are also free to move between the countries
baseline: If people are also free to move between the countries, in addition to a free-trade agreement, it would also be considered an open border.

prompts: This means that one pair of shoes can be produced by six countries
baseline: This means that one pair of shoes can be produced by six countries, each contributing to a part of the production process.

prompts: The cultural diffusion can create a homogenizing force , where
baseline: The cultural diffusion can create a homogenizing force, where globalization is seen as synonymous with homogenizing force via connectedness of markets, cultures, politics and the desire for modernizations through imperial countries sphere of influence.

prompts: Globalization gave support to the world music phenomenon by allowing music from developing
baseline: Globalization gave support to the world music phenomenon by allowing music from developing countries to reach broader audiences.

prompts: A 2005 UNESCO report showed that cultural exchange is becoming more frequent from
baseline: A 2005 UNESCO report showed that cultural exchange is becoming more frequent from Eastern Asia, but that Western countries are still the main exporters of cultural goods.

prompts: Americanization is related to a period of high political American clout and of significant growth of America 's shops , markets and objects being brought into other countries
baseline: Americanization is related to a period of high political American clout and of significant growth of America's shops, markets and objects being brought into other countries.

prompts: Some argue that globalization may ultimately lead to Westernization or
baseline: Some argue that globalization may ultimately lead to Westernization or Americanization of culture, where the dominating cultural concepts of economically and politically powerful Western countries spread and cause harm to local cultures.

prompts: Globalization is a diverse phenomenon that relates to a multilateral
baseline: Globalization is a diverse phenomenon that relates to a multilateral political world and to the increase of cultural objects and markets between countries.

prompts: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation projects include a current multibillion
baseline: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation projects include a current multibillion-dollar commitment to funding immunizations in some of the world's more impoverished but rapidly growing countries.

prompts: The Hudson Institute estimates total private philanthropic flows to developing countries
baseline: The Hudson Institute estimates total private philanthropic flows to developing countries at US$59 billion in 2010.

prompts: Some countries – such as those in the Schengen Area – have agreements with other
baseline: Some countries – such as those in the Schengen Area – have agreements with other countries allowing each other's citizens to travel between them without visas (for example, Switzerland is part of a Schengen Agreement allowing easy travel for people from countries within the European Union).

prompts: More and more students are seeking higher education in foreign countries and many international students now consider overseas study a
baseline: More and more students are seeking higher education in foreign countries and many international students now consider overseas study a stepping-stone to permanent residency within a country.

prompts: A transnational marriage is a marriage between
baseline: A transnational marriage is a marriage between two people from different countries.

prompts: A variety of special issues arise in marriages between people from different countries , including those related to
baseline: A variety of special issues arise in marriages between people from different countries, including those related to citizenship and culture, which add complexity and challenges to these kinds of relationships.

prompts: More than 180 countries have reported cases since then
baseline: More than 180 countries have reported cases since then.

baseline: More than 3.4 million people from the worst-affected countries entered the U.S. in the first three months since the inception of the COVID-19 pandemic.

prompts: Less educated workers , who were more likely to compete with immigrants and
baseline: Less educated workers, who were more likely to compete with immigrants and workers in developing countries, tended to be opponents.

prompts: Many in developing countries see globalization as a positive force that lifts them out of
baseline: Many in developing countries see globalization as a positive force that lifts them out of poverty.

baseline: In a 2006 survey of 83 American economists, "87.5% agree that the U.S. should eliminate remaining tariffs and other barriers to trade" and "90.1% disagree with the suggestion that the U.S. should restrict employers from outsourcing work to foreign countries."

prompts: Jagdish Bhagwati , a former adviser to the U.N. on globalization , holds that , although
baseline: Jagdish Bhagwati, a former adviser to the U.N. on globalization, holds that, although there are obvious problems with overly rapid development, globalization is a very positive force that lifts countries out of poverty by causing a virtuous economic cycle associated with faster economic growth.

prompts: An IMF study noted a potential for skills to be transferred back to developing
baseline: An IMF study noted a potential for skills to be transferred back to developing countries as wages in those a countries rise.

prompts: In particular , in East Asian developing countries , GDP
baseline: In particular, in East Asian developing countries, GDP per head rose at 5.9% a year from 1975 to 2001 (according to 2003 Human Development Report of UNDP).

prompts: Like this , the British economic journalist Martin Wolf says that incomes of
baseline: Like this, the British economic journalist Martin Wolf says that incomes of poor developing countries, with more than half the world's population, grew substantially faster than those of the world's richest countries that remained relatively stable in its growth, leading to reduced international inequality and the incidence of poverty.

prompts: Of the factors influencing the duration of economic growth in both developed and developing countries , income
baseline: Of the factors influencing the duration of economic growth in both developed and developing countries, income equality has a more beneficial impact than trade openness, sound political institutions, and foreign investment.

prompts: Also , adult literacy in developing countries rose from 53 %
baseline: Also, adult literacy in developing countries rose from 53% in 1970 to 74% in 1998 and much lower illiteracy rate among the young guarantees that rates will continue to fall as time passes.

prompts: Thus , despite seemingly unequal distribution of income within these developing countries , their
baseline: Thus, despite seemingly unequal distribution of income within these developing countries, their economic growth and development have brought about improved standards of living and welfare for the population as a whole.

prompts: Per capita gross domestic product ( GDP ) growth among post-1980 globalizing countries accelerated from 1.4 percent
baseline: Per capita gross domestic product (GDP) growth among post-1980 globalizing countries accelerated from 1.4 percent a year in the 1960s and 2.9 percent a year in the 1970s to 3.5 percent in the 1980s and 5.0 percent in the 1990s.

prompts: This acceleration in growth seems even more remarkable given that the rich
baseline: This acceleration in growth seems even more remarkable given that the rich countries saw steady declines in growth from a high of 4.7 percent in the 1960s to 2.2 percent in the 1990s.

prompts: Also , the non - globalizing developing countries seem to
baseline: Also, the non-globalizing developing countries seem to fare worse than the globalizers, with the former's annual growth rates falling from highs of 3.3 percent during the 1970s to only 1.4 percent during the 1990s.

prompts: They also claim that the increasing autonomy and strength of corporate entities shapes the political policy
baseline: They also claim that the increasing autonomy and strength of corporate entities shapes the political policy of countries.

prompts: While it is true that free trade encourages globalization among countries
baseline: While it is true that free trade encourages globalization among countries, some countries try to protect their domestic suppliers.

prompts: The main export of poorer countries is usually agricultural productions
baseline: The main export of poorer countries is usually agricultural productions.
